word.description:
{包} is *bun* (specifically a filled bun), and more generally denotes a *package* or *bag*, which the character resembles.

In Mandarin, {包} is suffixed with {子}, which generally denotes small things or offspring (the character resembles a baby with its arms spread).

{包} is also part of 打包 (dá bāau), which you say to indicate you want leftovers wrapped up to go.

images.place: KJ Dim Sum and Seafood, Las Vegas, Nevada

description: [Bao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baozi), a core component of classic dim sum, are wheat buns (mostly steamed, but some are baked or pan-fried), with various fillings (non-filled bao are called [mantou](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mantou), the original name for filled and non-filled bao and still used that way in some regions).

word.description:
{大}is *big* (the character looks like a person with arms spread), and {包} is *bun* (specifically a filled bun - non-filled is [mantou](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mantou), so {大包} is *big bun*.

Not to be confused with {打包} (dá bāau), which you say to indicate you want leftovers wrapped/boxed/bagged to go.

description: An [extra large](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Da_Bao) steamed [bao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baozi) (a meal in itself) typically filled with minced pork or chicken, Chinese sausage,boiled egg, or alterntively vegetables.

word.description: {芋頭} is [taro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taro), and {包} is *bun*, so 芋頭包 is *taro bun*.

images.place: KJ Dim Sum and Seafood, Las Vegas, Nevada

word.description: {雞} is *chicken*, and {包} is *bun*, so 雞包 is *chicken bun*.

images.place: Dim Sum Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
[Bao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baozi) with thick dough, twisted at the top, containing chicken, other meat (pork/sausage/shrimp) and items such as black mushroom.

**History**

Originated in northern China.

word.description: {生} is *raw*, and {煎} is *pan-fried*, so {生煎包} is *raw-fried bun*.

images.place: Ping Pang Pong, Las Vegas, Nevada

description: A thick pan-fried [bao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baozi) with a juicy pork mixture inside, also known by its Mandarin pronunciation as *Shengjian bao*, *Shengjian bun*, or [Shengian mantou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shengjian_mantou).
